overview.title: What are Collective Nouns?
overview.description: Collective nouns name groups of people, animals, or things considered as a single unit. They are used to refer to collections, making sentences shorter and clearer.
key_points: May refer to people, animals, or objects
Singular in form but may take singular or plural verbs
Examples: team, family, flock, bunch, committee
overview.importance: Collective nouns help describe groups efficiently, making language more expressive and less repetitive.

sections.title: Definition and Function
sections.content: A collective noun refers to a group of people, animals, or things as a single entity. Even though it names multiple individuals, it often behaves like a singular noun in grammar.

subsections.subtitle: Single Unit Concept
subsections.text: The group is thought of as one whole, not as separate members. For example, 'A team is playing.'
examples: A class is taking the test.

sections.title: Usage in Sentences
sections.content: Collective nouns can take singular or plural verbs, depending on whether you're emphasizing the group as a whole or the individuals within it. This varies between American and British English usage.

subsections.subtitle: Verb Agreement
subsections.text: In American English, collective nouns usually use singular verbs. In British English, both singular and plural verbs may be correct depending on context.
examples: The team are wearing their new jerseys. (UK)

sections.title: Types of Collective Nouns
sections.content: Some collective nouns are general (like 'group'), while others are specific to certain objects, animals, or professions.

subsections.subtitle: Specific Examples
subsections.text: Words such as 'flock' for birds, 'herd' for cattle, and 'panel' for judges are examples of specialized collective nouns.

grammar_rules.title: Use singular verbs when the group acts as one
grammar_rules.description: Treat the collective noun as singular if the group performs the same action collectively.
correct_examples: The class is studying for the test.
incorrect_examples: The audience were excited. (incorrect in US English)
grammar_rules.tip: Check if the group is acting together‚Äîuse singular verbs.

grammar_rules.title: Use plural verbs when group members act as individuals
grammar_rules.description: If the action is performed by individuals in the group, use a plural verb (especially in British English).
correct_examples: The team are discussing among themselves.
The class are working on projects.
The family are taking their seats.
incorrect_examples: The team is discussing among themselves.
The class is working on projects.
The family is taking their seats.
grammar_rules.tip: If you mean individuals, use a plural verb (common in UK English).

grammar_rules.title: Make collective nouns plural when referring to groups of groups
grammar_rules.description: When discussing more than one group, pluralize the collective noun itself.
correct_examples: There are three teams in this league.
Two herds of cattle were seen.
incorrect_examples: Two herd of cattle were seen.
grammar_rules.tip: Pluralize the collective noun to refer to multiple groups.

grammar_rules.title: Use articles and quantifiers appropriately
grammar_rules.description: Most collective nouns need an article or number when used in a sentence.
grammar_rules.tip: Use 'a', 'the', or quantifiers like 'some' before collective nouns.

grammar_rules.title: Context determines subject-verb agreement
grammar_rules.description: Decide verb number by whether you mean the group (singular) or the members (plural) in the context.
correct_examples: The audience is clapping loudly. (whole group)
The jury are arguing among themselves. (individuals within the group)
incorrect_examples: The audience are clapping loudly. (in US English)
The jury is arguing among themselves.
grammar_rules.tip: Ask: Is the group acting as one or as individuals?

common_mistakes.wrong: The family are going to the airport. (in US English)
common_mistakes.correct: The family is going to the airport.
common_mistakes.explanation: Treat as singular in American English.
common_mistakes.tip: Use a singular verb unless emphasizing individuals.

common_mistakes.wrong: Three flock of birds were seen.
common_mistakes.correct: Three flocks of birds were seen.
common_mistakes.explanation: Pluralize the collective noun when talking about multiple groups.
common_mistakes.tip: Pluralize to show more than one group.

common_mistakes.explanation: Collective nouns need articles when indefinite.
common_mistakes.tip: Use 'a', 'the', or quantifiers before most collective nouns.

common_mistakes.wrong: He has a family of brother.
common_mistakes.correct: He has a family of brothers.
common_mistakes.explanation: Group noun should not be followed by a singular.
common_mistakes.tip: Use pluralized members after the group noun.

common_mistakes.wrong: The committee have made a decision.
common_mistakes.correct: The committee has made a decision.
common_mistakes.explanation: Use singular verb for group acting as one (US standard).

common_mistakes.wrong: A bunches of keys is missing.
common_mistakes.correct: A bunch of keys is missing.
common_mistakes.explanation: Do not pluralize when using the collective noun for a single group.
common_mistakes.tip: Pluralize only if referring to more than one group.
Learn spelling of common collective nouns.

common_mistakes.error_type: Wrong use of collective with uncountable
common_mistakes.wrong: A herd of rice is growing.
common_mistakes.correct: A field of rice is growing.
common_mistakes.explanation: Use correct collective noun for the item.
common_mistakes.tip: Check standard group words for objects.

answer: The team is ready to play.
questions.explanation: Use singular verb for collective acting as one.

answer: Three fleets of ships sailed by.

answer: A bunch of bananas was on the table.
